Description: Lower wall sherd of Attic black-figured pottery little-master cup; interior: tondo framed by band of alternating red and black tongues between lines; in tondo, remains of circular object; outside, black-figure decoration consisting of fallen warrior (only outstreched leg remaining), possibly trampled by horse (front hoofs remaining); to right, figure standing to left, probably a hoplite (legs remaining); traces of black on break; below, three lines and glazed lower bowl.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Venit identifies the sherd as belonging to a Type A or Sub-A cup but the decoration is more consistent with Attic Siana and little master cups.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 90, no. 309, pl. 67)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1334) (phase 3)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 431, no. B691, pl. CCX)
